aboutYou.h2.title: Information About You
aboutYou.label.claimedAsDependent: I am claimed as a dependent on someone else’s tax return
aboutYou.label.filingStatus: What filing status will you use for your tax return?
aboutYou.label.is65OrOlder: I will be 65 or older on Jan. 1, :futureYear
aboutYou.label.is65OrOlderSpouse: My spouse will be 65 or older on Jan. 1, :futureYear
aboutYou.label.jobOrPension: Do you (or will you) have a job that regularly withholds federal income taxes from your paychecks?
aboutYou.label.jobOrPensionMFJ: Do you (or will you) or your spouse have a job that regularly withholds federal income taxes from your paychecks?
aboutYou.label.numOfDependents: How many dependents do you plan on claiming on your tax return this year?
aboutYou.label.willClaimDependents: I plan to claim dependents on my tax return (You will enter information about your dependents on the Tax Credits page)
aboutYou.li.filingStatusTT1: You were entitled to file a joint return with your spouse for the year your spouse died. It does not matter whether you actually filed a joint return.
aboutYou.li.filingStatusTT2: Your spouse died no more than two years before the year for which you are filing your return and you did not remarry before the end of the year for which you are filing your return.
aboutYou.li.filingStatusTT3: You have a child or stepchild whom you may claim as a dependent. This does not include a foster child.
aboutYou.li.filingStatusTT4: This child lived in your home all year, except for temporary absences. There are also exceptions for a child who was born or died during the year and for a kidnapped child.
aboutYou.li.filingStatusTT5: You paid more than half the cost of keeping up a home for the year.
aboutYou.li.numOfDependentsTT2: Students under the age of 24 who live with their parents; or
aboutYou.li.numOfDependentsTT3: Or other relatives who live with you and whose care you are responsible for.
aboutYou.li.numOfEitcTT2: Students under the age of 24 who live with their parents; or
aboutYou.li.numOfEitcTT3: Or other relatives who live with you and whose care you are responsible for.
aboutYou.li.blindTT1: You can't see better than 20/200 in the better eye with glasses or contact lenses, or your field of vision is 20 degrees or less.
aboutYou.li.blindTT2: If your eye condition isn't likely to improve beyond these limits, the statement should include this fact. Keep the statement in your records.
aboutYou.li.blindTT3: If your vision can be corrected beyond these limits only by contact lenses that you can wear only briefly because of pain, infection, or ulcers, you can take the higher standard deduction for blindness if you otherwise qualify.
aboutYou.p.claimedAsDependentTT1: Most people under the age of 19 and most students under the age of 24 who live with their parents or other relatives are dependents and should select 'Yes' here.
aboutYou.p.claimedAsDependentTT2: A married taxpayer filing a joint return may not be claimed as a dependent unless they are filing only to claim a refund of taxes paid and should usually select 'No' here. We will ask about your dependents later.
aboutYou.p.claimedAsDependentTT3: For more information about whether someone can claim you as a dependent, see :irsWhoMayIClaim.
aboutYou.p.filingStatusTT1: Generally, you may claim Head of Household filing status on your tax return only if you are unmarried and pay more than 50% of the costs of keeping up a home for yourself and your dependent(s) or other qualifying individuals.
aboutYou.p.filingStatusTT3: You are eligible to file your return as a qualifying widow(er) with dependent child if you meet all of the following tests.
aboutYou.p.fsClaimedWarning: It is rare that someone can claim either a married or head of household status if they can be claimed as a dependent on someone else's tax return. If you are sure that you qualify you may proceed. If not, start over.
aboutYou.p.jobOrPensionTT1: If you're an employee, your employer probably withholds income tax from your paycheck and pays it to the IRS in your name. The app does not provide recommendations for W-4P anymore. To have tax withheld from a pension, complete a Form W-4P and give it to your pension provider. The pension provider will determine the correct amount to withhold considering all the other income you have. If you have a job and a pension, then you can use the estimator to withhold both incomes from your W-4.
aboutYou.p.jobOrPensionWarning1: You have indicated that you do not have income from a job that is subject to periodic federal tax withholding. Since you are not subject to tax withholding, this tool won’t work for you. If you made an error in previous entries, correct it, or start over.  For more information, see :irsPub505.
aboutYou.p.numOfDependentsTT1: A dependent is usually, but not always, a child or other relative who meets a set of criteria. A dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or resident alien. Most dependents include:
aboutYou.p.numOfDependentsTT2: For more information about dependents visit :whomMayIClaim.
aboutYou.p.subtitle: Select the information that best describes how you anticipate filing your :year tax return.
aboutYou.p.willClaimDependentsTT1: A dependent is usually, but not always, a child or other relative who meets a set of criteria. A dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or resident alien. Most dependents include:
aboutYou.p.willClaimDependentsTT2: For more information about dependents, see :irsWhoWillClaim

adjustments.h2.title: Adjustments to Income
adjustments.p.portionOfAdjustments: The portion of adjustments you are allowed to claim may be different and will be displayed on the results page
adjustments.label.adjustments: Select any adjustments to income you plan to make when you file your :year income taxes or go to the next step.
adjustments.label.business: Certain business credits for reservists, performing artists, and fee-based government officials
adjustments.label.earlyWithdrawal: Penalty for Early Withdrawal of Savings
adjustments.label.hsa: Health Savings Account Deduction (excluding amounts deducted from payroll)
adjustments.label.ira: Deduction for contributions to an IRA (excluding amounts deducted from payroll)
adjustments.label.moving: Moving Expenses for Members of the Armed Services
adjustments.label.sepSimple: Contributions to self-employed SEP, SIMPLE, or other qualified plans
adjustments.label.sepSimpleSpouse: Contributions to spouse’s self-employed SEP, SIMPLE, or other qualified plans
adjustments.label.studentLoanCallout: Student Loan Interest is capped at $2500
adjustments.p.alimonyTT1: Amounts paid to a spouse or a former spouse under a divorce or separation instrument (including a divorce decree, a separate maintenance decree, or a written separation agreement) may be alimony for federal tax purposes. Alimony is deductible by the payer spouse, and the recipient spouse must include it in income.
adjustments.p.alimonyTT2: :irsNoteBold You can't deduct alimony or separate maintenance payments made under a divorce or separation agreement (1) executed after :pastYear, or (2) executed before :currentYear but later modified if the modification expressly states the repeal of the deduction for alimony payments applies to the modification. Alimony and separate maintenance payments you receive under such an agreement are not included in your gross income. For more information visit :irsTopic452
adjustments.p.businessTT1: Form 2106 is used by Armed Forces reservists, qualified performing artists, fee-basis state or local government officials, and employees with impairment-related work expenses to figure their deductible business expenses.
adjustments.p.businessTT2: Due to the suspension of miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% floor under section 67(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, employees who do not fit into one of the listed categories may not claim adjustments for these expenses.
adjustments.p.earlyWithdrawalTT1: If you withdraw funds from a certificate of deposit or other deferred interest account before maturity, you may be charged a penalty. The Form 1099-INT or 1099-OID given to you by the financial institution will show the penalty you are charged.
adjustments.p.educatorTT1: If you're an eligible educator, you can deduct up to $250 ($500 if married filing jointly and both spouses are eligible educators, but not more than $250 each) of unreimbursed trade or business expenses. Qualified expenses are amounts you paid or incurred for participation in professional development courses, books, supplies, computer equipment (including related software and services), other equipment, and supplementary materials that you use in the classroom.
adjustments.p.hsaTT1: You may be eligible to deduct health savings account contribution not included in your payroll deductions.
adjustments.p.iraTT1: You may be able to claim a deduction on IRA contributions made outside of your payroll contributions.
adjustments.p.movingTT1: If you're a member of the Armed Forces on active duty, you may be eligible to deduct moving expenses if your move was due to a military order and permanent change of station. You may be able to deduct your unreimbursed moving expenses for you, your spouse and dependents.
adjustments.p.skipAhead: You may be eligible for some Adjustments based on the information you entered in :aboutYou and :incomeWithholding . You need to complete those steps before advancing to this step.
adjustments.p.studentLoanTT1: Student loan interest is interest you paid during the year on a qualified student loan. It includes both required and voluntarily pre-paid interest payments. You may deduct the lesser of $2,500 or the amount of interest you actually paid during the year.
adjustments.p.subtitle: Most taxpayers don't have a large enough adjustment to have a significant impact on their tax obligation.
deductionPayments.li.paidTT1: State, local, and foreign income taxes
deductionPayments.li.paidTT2: State and local general sales taxes
deductionPayments.li.paidTT3: State and local real estate taxes
deductionPayments.li.paidTT4: State and local personal property taxes
deductionPayments.li.qualifiedTT1: Investment interest (limited to your net investment income)
deductionPayments.li.qualifiedTT2: Qualified mortgage interest including points (if you're the buyer)
deductionPayments.p.casualtyTT1: Generally, you may deduct casualty and theft losses relating to your home, household items, and vehicles on your federal income tax return if the loss took place in a federally declared disaster area (declared by the President). You may not deduct casualty and theft losses covered by insurance, unless you file a timely claim for reimbursement and you reduce the loss by the amount of any reimbursement or expected reimbursement.
deductionPayments.p.charityTT1: To be a deductible, you must make charitable contributions to qualified organizations. Contributions to individuals are never deductible. To determine if the organization that you contributed to qualifies as a charitable organization for income tax deduction purposes, refer to our :irsTopicTaxExempt
deductionPayments.p.medicalTT1: If you want to deduct medical and dental expenses you pay this year for yourself, your spouse and your dependents, you can deduct only the amount of your total expenses that exceed 7.5% of your adjusted gross income.
deductionPayments.p.medicalTT2: Enter your total estimated medical and dental expenses. You may include the total estimated amount you pay for health insurance premiums, not including any amount your employer pays. The estimator will determine the amount you can claim and reflect it on the results page summary table.
deductionPayments.p.otherTT2: For information on other deductions see :irsTopic529
deductionPayments.p.paidTT1: There are four types of deductible nonbusiness taxes:
deductionPayments.p.paidTT3: Note: this deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 ($5,000 for married taxpayers filing separately). The tool will apply this limit for you, if necessary.
deductionPayments.p.qualifiedTT1: Interest is an amount you pay for the use of borrowed money. Some interest can be claimed as a deduction or as a credit. To deduct interest you paid on a debt, review each interest expense to determine how it qualifies and where to take the deduction. Itemized Deductions include:

deductions.bold.deductions: You qualify for the standard deduction of :amount
deductions.h2.title: Deductions From Income
deductions.label.deductionPayments: Select the itemized deductions that may apply to you:
deductions.label.deductions: :bold. Would you like to itemize your deductions or take the standard deduction? Most people take the standard deduction.
deductions.label.itemized: Use my itemized deduction even if it is less than my standard deduction
deductions.label.itemizedCalculations: If your itemized deductions are less than your standard deduction, the tool will use the standard deduction.
deductions.p.deductionsTT1: The standard deduction is a specific dollar amount that reduces the amount of income subject to tax. Your standard deduction amount depends on your filing status, dependency status, age, whether or not you are blind. Alternatively, you may itemize your deductions, which would be to your advantage if your total itemized deductions exceed your standard deduction. If you're unsure if you should take the standard deduction or itemize you can view deductions and input them. The tool will then determine which is higher for you.
deductions.p.deductionsTT2: For more information about determining if you should take the standard deduction or itemize see :irsTopic501
deductions.p.mfsInfoAlertHeading: If your spouse itemized deductions, then you must.
deductions.p.skipAhead: The tool will automatically determine the standard deduction for which you are eligible based on the information you enter in the previous steps. Complete the previous steps before advancing to this page.
deductions.p.subtitle: Deductions reduce the amount of your income subject to income tax.
deductions.p.portionOfItemizedDeductions: The portion of itemized deductions you are allowed to claim may be different and will be displayed on the results page

incomeWithholding.label.retirementPastMF: My spouse or I contributed to a 401k
incomeWithholding.label.ssiAllYear: Will you receive Social Security payments all year?
incomeWithholding.label.ssiAllYearMFJ: Will you or your spouse receive Social Security payments all year?
incomeWithholding.label.ssiMonthlyAmount: Enter the total amount of the monthly Social Security payments you receive before any taxes, benefits, or other items are subtracted
Enter your monthly Social Security payments you will receive before any taxes, premiums, or other items are subtracted
Enter the total amount of the monthly Social Security payments you receive, or your spouse receives, before any taxes, benefits, or other items are subtracted
Enter the total amount of the monthly Social Security payments you or your spouse will receive before any taxes, benefits, or other items are subtracted
incomeWithholding.label.taxesPerPayPerio: Enter federal taxes paid per pay period
Using your most recent Social Security statement, enter the total federal income taxes withheld per Social Security payment:
Using your or your spouse’s most recent Social Security statement, enter the total federal income taxes withheld per Social Security payment:
incomeWithholding.label.taxesYTDSsiAllYe: Using your most recent Social Security statement, enter the total federal income taxes withheld Year-to-date:
Using your or your spouse’s most recent Social Security statement, enter the total federal income taxes withheld Year-to-date:
incomeWithholding.label.timePeriodOfJob: Select what best describes when you earn income from this job:
incomeWithholding.label.timePeriodOfJobM: Select what best describes when you or your spouse earn income from this job:
incomeWithholding.label.timePeriodOfPens: Select what best describes when you earn income from this pension:
Select what best describes when you or your spouse earn income from this pension:
incomeWithholding.label.wagesPerPayPerio: Enter wages or salary per pay period
incomeWithholding.label.wagesYTDHourly: Enter wages earned Year-to-date from your most recent paystub
incomeWithholding.label.wagesYTDHourlyMF: Enter wages earned Year-to-date from your or your spouse’s most recent paystub
incomeWithholding.label.wagesYTDPensionA: Enter total pension payment amount Year-to-date
incomeWithholding.label.wagesYTDPensionP: Enter pension payment amount earned Year-to-date
incomeWithholding.li.401kTT1: Cash or deferred arrangements (section 401(k) or 403(b) plans, but not Roth plans);
incomeWithholding.li.401kTT2: Section 457 plans, but not Roth plans;
incomeWithholding.li.401kTT3: The Thrift Savings Plan for federal employees, but not Roth plans;
incomeWithholding.li.401kTT4: Salary reduction simplified employee pension (SARSEP) plans;
incomeWithholding.li.cafeteriaPlanTT1: Coverage under accident and health insurance plans, other than long-term care.
incomeWithholding.li.cafeteriaPlanTT2: Coverage under dependent care assistance plans.
incomeWithholding.li.cafeteriaPlanTT3: Group-term life insurance on the lives of employees.
incomeWithholding.li.scholarshipTT1: Amounts used for incidental expenses, such as room and board, travel, and optional equipment.
incomeWithholding.li.scholarshipTT2: Amounts received as payments for teaching, research, or other services required as a condition for receiving the scholarship or fellowship grant.
incomeWithholding.p.annualSalary: Enter the total amount you expect to receive from this job this year. This includes your gross (pre-tax) wages, salary, and tips you expect to receive as compensation for your job before contributions for any tax-favored benefits such as a section 401(k) plan or health insurance premiums and before any deductions for taxes. Do not include bonuses here. The tool will determine how much you will get this year.
incomeWithholding.p.bonusTT1: Supplemental wages are wage payments to an employee that aren't regular wages. They include, but aren't limited to bonuses, commissions, overtime pay, payments for accumulated sick leave, severance pay, awards, prizes, back pay, retroactive pay increases, and payments for nondeductible moving expenses.
incomeWithholding.p.bonusTT2: Other payments subject to supplemental wage rules include taxable fringe benefits and expense allowances paid under a nonaccountable plan.
incomeWithholding.p.cafeteriaPlanTT1: These are pre-tax contributions (payroll deductions) that may include any of the following:
incomeWithholding.p.dateRangeSSITT1: Select the dates you expect to collect income from Social Security this year
incomeWithholding.p.dateRangeSSITT2: For example, if you do not currently collect income from Social Security, but expect to begin collecting it later this year, select the date you expect to start collecting it as the start date and December 31 as the end date.
incomeWithholding.p.dateRangeTT1: Select the dates you expect to hold this job this year.
incomeWithholding.p.dateRangeTT2: For example, if you held the job at the beginning of the year and no longer do, select January 1 as the start date and your final day at the job as the end date. If you got a new job and expect to hold it the rest of the year, select the date started this job as the start date and December 31 as the end date.
incomeWithholding.p.incomeTypeTT1: :salaryBold you generally get paid the same amount of money every pay period, regardless of the number of hours you worked.
incomeWithholding.p.incomeTypeTT2: :hourlyBold you’re paid an hourly wage, so your income could vary by the number of hours you work in a pay period.
incomeWithholding.p.incomeTypeTT3: :pensionBold These are regular (e.g, monthly) payments you collect after you retire from your job. To have tax withheld from a pension, complete a Form W-4P and give it to your pension provider. The pension provider will determine the correct amount to withhold considering all the other income you have. If you have a job and a pension, then you can use the estimator to withhold both incomes from your W-4.
incomeWithholding.p.incomeTypeTT4: :ssiBold These are payments you receive from the Social Security Administration for old age or disability benefits. Do not include any Supplemental Security Income payments you or your spouse receive.
incomeWithholding.p.incomeTypeTT5: To use this tool, you need to have a job subject to tax withholding. If you enter information for a job first, you will be able to enter your Social Security benefits information later. For more information, see :incomePub505.
incomeWithholding.p.investmentsTT1: Investment income includes interest, dividends, net capital gains, royalty income, rental income from personal property, and income from passive activities reported on Schedule E.
incomeWithholding.p.investmentsTT2: For more information about investment income, see :whatIsEarnedIncome
incomeWithholding.p.noIncomeTypeWarning: You have indicated that you do not have (or will have) income from a job that is subject to periodic federal tax withholding. Since you are not subject to tax withholding, this tool won’t work for you. If you made an error in previous entries, correct it, or start over.
incomeWithholding.p.otherTaxableIncomeTT: You can receive income in the form of annuities, alimony, and distributions from an IRA (not Roth IRAs), 401(k) or a trust.
incomeWithholding.p.otherTaxesTT1: This could include any prior-year tax refund applied towards this year’s tax obligation, estimated tax payments, backup withholding, or additional federal income tax withholding from dividends, interest, annuities, or a distribution from an IRA (not Roth IRAs), 401(k) or a trust. This does not include withholding from wages, pension, self-employment income, unemployment compensation or social security.
incomeWithholding.p.payFrequencyTT1: This is how often you receive a paycheck from your employer/pension. Typically, this is weekly, every two weeks, twice a month, or once a month.
incomeWithholding.p.pensionPayFrequencyT: This is how often you receive a pension payment from your pension. Typically, this is weekly, every other two weeks, twice a month, or once a month.
incomeWithholding.p.retirementTT1: Amounts that you may enter here include payroll deductions to the following retirement plans:
incomeWithholding.p.scholarshipTT1: If you receive a scholarship, a fellowship grant, or other grant, all or part of the amounts you receive may be tax-free. Scholarships, fellowship grants, and other grants can be tax-free if the amounts you receive are used to pay for tuition and fees required for enrollment or attendance at the educational institution, or for fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for courses at the educational institution.
incomeWithholding.p.scholarshipTT2: You must include in gross income:
incomeWithholding.p.scholarshipTT3: However, you don't need to include in gross income any amounts you receive for services that are required by the National Health Service Corps Scholarship Program, the Armed Forces Health Professions Scholarship and Financial Assistance Program, or a comprehensive student work-learning-service program (as defined in section 448(e) of the Higher Education Act of 1965) operated by a work college. For more information, see :irsTopic421.
incomeWithholding.p.selfEmploymentTT1: This is the amount of income (such as professional fees paid to you or your spouse and any other compensation you or your spouse expect to receive for work performed in your or your spouse’s business) minus deductible expenses.
incomeWithholding.p.skipAhead: The tool will ask you to enter your income and any taxes withheld based on the types of income you indicate on the :aboutYou1 page in order to determine whether you are having too much or too little withheld. You must complete :aboutYou2 before advancing to this page.
incomeWithholding.p.ssiBenefitsYTD: Social security benefits can be taxable and affect your total income, impacting your annual tax obligation.
incomeWithholding.p.ssiBenefitsYTDTT2: For more information about social security benefits see :irsTopic423.
incomeWithholding.p.ssiEarlyWarning1: You have indicated that you receive monthly Social Security benefits. However, to use this tool, you need to have a job or a pension subject to tax withholding. If you enter information for a job or a pension first, you will be able to enter your Social Security benefits information later.
incomeWithholding.p.subtitle: Enter information for each job you will earn income from this year. To use this tool, you need to have a job subject to tax withholding.  If you have Social Security or pension income and you prefer to have tax withheld from your job to cover that additional income, select 2 or more sources of income, and enter information for your job first. After that, you will be able to enter your Social Security and pension income.
incomeWithholding.p.taxesPaidWarning: Your taxes paid per pay period is more than your year to date
incomeWithholding.p.taxesPerPayPeriodTT1: The amount of money withheld by your employer/pension for federal income tax is listed on each pay statement you receive. This does not include state, local, Medicare, Social Security, or other amounts withheld.
incomeWithholding.p.wagesYTDTT1: Enter the total amount you expect to receive from this job this year. This includes your gross (pre-tax) wages, salary, and tips you expect to receive as compensation for your job before contributions for any tax-favored benefits such as a section 401(k) plan or health insurance premiums and before any deductions for taxes. Do not include bonuses.
otherIncome.a.investmentsRequiredError: Error: An amount is required to continue.
otherIncome.a.otherTaxableIncomeRequired: Error: An amount is required to continue.
otherIncome.a.otherTaxesRequiredError: Error: An amount is required to continue.
otherIncome.a.scholarshipRequiredError: Error: An amount is required to continue.
otherIncome.a.selfEmploymentRequiredErro: Error: An amount is required to continue.
otherIncome.a.unemploymentRequiredError: Error: An amount is required to continue.

results.h2.title: Results
results.label.is65OrOlder: You will be 65 or older on January 1, :year
results.label.is65OrOlderSpouse: Your spouse will be 65 or older on January 1, :year
results.label.willClaimDependents: I plan to claim dependents on my tax return
results.li.firstAsterisk: * This is your projected withholding for the year if you make no changes and do not submit a new Form W-4. This number includes Federal income tax withheld and any estimated tax paid.
results.li.firstAsteriskDecMsg: * This is your projected withholding for the year. This number includes Federal income tax withheld and any estimated tax already paid
results.li.pensionAccordionList2: On line 2, check the box for :filingStatus filing status
results.li.pensionAccordionList4: Enter :withholding in additional withholding per pay period (Line 3 on :link is already pre-filled). This is an amount of withholding over and above the standard withholding from each pension payment if lines 2 and 3 of the Form W-4P were blank or zero.
results.li.pensionAccordionList5: If using a paper form sign and date it
results.li.secondAsterisk: ** This is your expected tax liability for the :currentYear1 tax year reported on the :currentYear2 Form 1040 due to be filed by April 15, :futureYear. This number includes Federal income tax before refundable credits, additional Medicare tax, and self-employment tax, if applicable.
results.li.ssiAsterisk: *** This tool is not yet equipped to create recommendations for withholding to Social Security incomeWithholding.
results.p.accuracyNote: :importantNote The accuracy of this estimate depends on the accuracy of the information you provide. The IRS makes no guarantees about the accuracy of this estimate and accepts no liability resulting from your use of the estimation.
results.p.adjustmentAccordionNotEnteredS: You have not entered any adjustments.
results.p.basedOnInfoEntered: Based on the information you entered
results.p.business: Certain business credits for reservists, performing artists, and fee-based government officials
results.p.childnDepCareTaxQualifyingPers: Child and Dependent Care Credit qualifying persons
results.p.claimedAsDependent: I am claimed as a dependent on someone else’s tax return
results.p.earlyWithdrawal: Penalty for early withdrawal of savings
results.p.energyRefuelingTaxCredit: Alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit
results.p.hsa: Health Savings Account Deduction (outside of those entered in payroll deductions)
results.p.ira: Deduction for contributions to an IRA (outside of deductions included in payroll deductions)
results.p.itemizedDeductions: You indicated that you want to use your itemized deductions instead of the standard deduction.
results.p.moving: Moving expenses for members of the armed services
results.p.numOfChildDependentCareQC: Child and Dependent Care Credit qualifying persons
results.p.numOfEitcQC: Earned Income Tax Credit number of qualifying children
results.p.oweLikely: you may owe taxes at the end of the year.
results.p.oweZero: your balance will be close to zero.
results.p.paid: State and local taxes you paid
results.p.paidAllowed: State and local taxes you paid (Allowed)
results.p.paidEntered: State and local taxes you paid (Entered)
results.p.pensionAccordionParagraph1: :step Check if your employer does this via paper or online
results.p.pensionAccordionParagraph2: :step Complete a new Form W-4P online or via paper as follows:
results.p.pensionAccordionParagraph3: :step Submit this new information to your employer as soon as possible
results.p.pensionIntroParagraphOver: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each pension payment, :amount2 less than your current tax withholding.
results.p.pensionIntroParagraphOweOver: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each pension payment, :amount2 more than your current tax withholding.
results.p.pensionIntroParagraphOweUnder: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each pension payment, :amount2 more than your current tax withholding. Remember that getting a larger refund could mean less take-home pay depending on your situation.
results.p.pensionIntroParagraphUnder: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each pension payment, :amount2 more than your current tax withholding. Remember that getting a larger refund could mean less take-home pay depending on your situation.
results.p.projectedWithheld: Expected total withheld or prepaid this year
results.p.refundLikely: you are likely to get a refund.
results.p.resultsRecommendationWarning1: The estimator will provide recommendations to adjust your Form W-4 and you wouldn't need to withhold directly from Social Security and/or pension income. Once the recommended Form W-4 is submitted that includes all your income, you wouldn’t need to submit a separate Form W-4P for pension or a separate Form W-4V for Social Security income.
results.p.resultsRecommendationWarning1b: The recommendations in this tool are designed to correct your withholding for the rest of this year based on whether you have had too much or too little federal income tax withheld to date. These adjustments are usually not appropriate for a full year, so you should use this estimator again at the beginning of next year to determine the appropriate full year amount.
results.p.resultsRecommendationWarning2: For questions on the results or recommendations, see our :faq.
results.p.rmdAccP1: These recommendations personalize your withholding to reach your desired refund amount.
results.p.rmdP1: This is your current projected refund amount. If you are happy with your results, you do not need to make any changes at this time.
results.p.rmdP3: Submitting a new Form W-4 resets your withholding to standard withholding if Lines 3 through 4c are blank or zero. Your standard withholding is :amount1 per paycheck based on your filing status and income. The recommendation for adjusting your withholding to get a refund of :amount2 will be based on the standard withholding amount, not your current withholding.
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph1: These recommendations personalize your withholding to reach your desired refund amount.
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph2: Edit a new Form W-4 online or via paper as follows:
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph3: :step Check (online) or enter (paper) your personal information (line 1(a) and (b) on Form W-4)
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph4: :step Select :filingStatus filing status (line 1(c) on Form W-4)
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph5Line3: :step Enter :amount1 for credits and other reductions to annual withholding (Line 3 on :link is already pre-filled).
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph5Line4: :step Enter :amount1 in additional withholding per pay period (Line 4(c) on :link is already pre-filled).
results.p.salaryAccordionParagraph6: :step If using a paper form sign and date it. Submit this personalized Form W-4 to your employer as soon as possible.
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph1Over: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck, :amount2 less than your current tax withholding.
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph1OweOver: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck, :amount2 less than your current tax withholding.
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph1OweUnder: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck, :amount2 more than your current tax withholding. Remember that getting a larger refund could mean less take-home pay depending on your situation.
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph1Under: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck, :amount2 more than your current tax withholding. Remember that getting a larger refund could mean less take-home pay depending on your situation.
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph2: Submitting a new Form W-4 resets your withholding to standard withholding if Lines 3 through 4c are blank or zero. Your standard withholding is :amount1 per paycheck based on your filing status and income. The recommendation for adjusting your withholding to get a refund of :amount2 will be based on the standard withholding amount, not your current withholding.
results.p.salaryIntroSalaryShutdown: To minimize your potential penalty and the amount you may owe when you file your return, consider making an estimated tax payment as soon as possible to cover the shortfall. For more information about making estimated payments, visit :estimatedTaxes. Make sure you're having the right amount withheld to meet your tax obligation next year by using next year's Tax Withholding Estimator early in the year.
results.p.scenarioLine3Less: This is an annual amount by which to reduce withholding below the standard withholding that would be withheld from each paycheck for this job if lines 3 through 4(c) of the Form W-4 were blank or zero.
results.p.scenarioLine3More: This is an annual amount by which to reduce withholding below the standard withholding from each paycheck for this job if lines 3 through 4(c) of the Form W-4 were blank or zero. This amount is greater than zero in your case, even though you need to increase withholding to achieve your desired refund. That is because your withholding to date has been lower than the standard amount of withholding to an even greater extent.
results.p.scenarioLine4Less: This is an amount of withholding over and above the standard withholding from each paycheck for this job if lines 3 through 4(c) of the Form W-4 were blank or zero.
results.p.scenarioLine4Less2: :evenThough That is because your withholding to date has exceeded the standard amount of withholding to an even greater extent.
results.p.scenarioLine4Less2Italic: Even though the amount on Line 4(c) is greater than zero, this recommendation would still result in a reduction in withholding relative to your current level of withholding.
results.p.scenarioLine4More: This is an amount of withholding over and above the standard withholding from each paycheck for this job if lines 3 through 4(c) of the Form W-4 were blank or zero.
results.p.seHealthInsuranceSpouse: Your spouse’s self-employed health insurance deduction
results.p.sepSimple: Contributions to self-employed SEP, SIMPLE, or other qualified plans
results.p.sepSimpleSpouse: Contributions to spouse's self-employed SEP, SIMPLE, or other qualified plans
results.p.shutDownWithholdingIntroParagr: Since you have already withheld significantly more than your anticipated tax obligation, this is the smallest possible refund that you could achieve even if you had nothing more withheld for the remainder of the year. See the recommendations below and consider using the estimator early next year for a higher likelihood of achieving your desired refund amount.
results.p.skipAhead: The tool will project the total amount of taxes being withheld now and compare it to an estimate of your tax obligation for the year in order to determine if you are having too much or too little withheld. The tool will then help you adjust your withholding accordingly using Form W-4.
results.p.sliderLabel1: Use the slider below to select the approximate refund amount you'd like to get.
results.p.taxableIncome: Taxable income (Adjusted Gross Income minus deductions)
results.p.taxCreditsAccordionEmpty: You have not entered any tax credits.
results.p.totalFedIncome: Total Federal income tax withheld to date
results.p.totalNonTax: Projected withheld for rest of year
results.p.totalTaxPaidSoFar: Total tax paid so far this year
results.p.totalTaxPaidThisYearIfNothing: Total tax paid this year if you do nothing
results.p.totalTaxPaidW4: Total tax paid this year if you submit a new Form W-4 as recommended
results.p.underShutDownWithholdingIntro: Based on your inputs and current tax situation, this result is not achievable at the moment. Consider using the estimator early next year for a higher likelihood of achieving your desired refund amount.
results.p.yourInfomrationSubtitle: The following is a recap of information entered on the preceding pages on which the above recommendation is based. Use the Edit buttons to go back to pages if you need to edit information.
results.span.otherTaxes: Total other Federal income tax payments to date
results.span.pensionProjectedTotalTax: Projected total tax withheld based on current Form W-4
results.span.pensionTotalFedIncome: Total Federal income tax withheld to date
results.span.projectedTotalTax: Projected total tax withheld based on current Form W-4
results.span.scholarship: Scholarship or grant that must be counted as income
results.span.selfEmploymentTaxPayments: Total estimated payments of Federal income tax towards self-employment income
results.span.totalFedIncome: Total Federal income tax withheld to date
results.span.unemploymentFedIncomeTaxWh: Federal income tax withheld from unemployment compensation
taxCredits.a.alternativeMinimumCreditTT1: About Form 8801, Credit for Prior Year Minimum Tax - Individuals, Estates, and Trusts
taxCredits.a.aotcTT1: Am I Eligible to Claim an Education Credit?
taxCredits.a.elderlyTaxCreditTT1: Credit for the Elderly or the Disabled at a Glance
taxCredits.a.energyMotorVehicleTaxCredit: About Form 8910, Alternative Motor Vehicle Credit
taxCredits.a.energyPlugInTaxCreditTT1: IRC 30D New Qualified Plug-In Electric Drive Motor Vehicle Credit
taxCredits.a.llcTT1: Am I Eligible to Claim an Education Credit?
taxCredits.h2.homeOwnerMortgageTaxCredit: Mortgage Interest Credit (for those with a qualified Mortgage Credit Certificate)
taxCredits.h2.title: Tax Credits
taxCredits.label.adoptionCreditAmount: Enter the amount of Adoption Tax Credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.alternativeMinimumCredi: Enter the amount of prior-year Alternative Minimum Tax credit
taxCredits.label.aotc: If you expect to be eligible for the American Opportunity Credit, enter the amount of credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.aotcCallout: The American Opportunity Tax Credit has a cap of $2,500 per student
taxCredits.label.childrenAges: Enter the age the child will be on December 31, :year
taxCredits.label.elderlyTaxCredit: Enter the amount of elderly or disabled credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.energyMotorVehicleTaxCr: Enter the amount of alternative motor vehicle credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.energyPlugInTaxCredit: Enter the amount of qualified plug-in electric vehicle credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.energyRefuelingTaxCredi: Enter the amount of alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.foreignTaxCredit: Enter the amount of Foreign Tax Credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.homeOwnerMortgageTaxCre: Mortgage Interest Credit (for those with a qualified Mortgage Credit Certificate)
taxCredits.label.llc: If you expect to be eligible for the Lifetime Learning Credit, enter the amount of credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.label.llcCallout: The Lifetime Learning Credit has an annual cap of $2000
taxCredits.label.numOfEitcQC: Enter the number of qualifying children for the Earned Income Tax Credit
taxCredits.label.numOfEitcQCCallout: The Earned Income Tax Credit is limited to 3 qualifying children.
taxCredits.label.numOfStudents: Enter the number of students you are claiming for the American Opportunity Tax Credit
taxCredits.label.retirementSavingsCredit: Enter the amount of any retirement savings contributions credit for which you expect to be eligible
taxCredits.li.numOfEitcTT1: Son, daughter, stepchild, “foster child”, brother, sister, stepbrother, stepsister, half-brother, half-sister, or a descendant of any of them (for example, your grandchild, niece, or nephew)
taxCredits.li.numOfEitcTT2: Under the age of 19 at the end of this year and younger than you (or your spouse, if filing jointly), or under the age of 24 at the end of this year, a “student”, and younger than you (or your spouse, if filing jointly), or any age and permanently and totally disabled
taxCredits.li.numOfEitcTT3: who isn't filing a joint return for this year or is filing a joint return for this year only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or estimated tax paid (see :irsTopic596 for examples)
taxCredits.li.numOfEitcTT4: Who lived with you in the United States for more than half of this year
taxCredits.p.adoptionCreditAmountTT1: Tax benefits for adoption include both a tax credit for qualified adoption expenses paid to adopt an eligible child and an exclusion from income for employer-provided adoption assistance.
taxCredits.p.alternativeMinimumCreditTT1: If you're not liable for AMT this year, but you paid AMT in one or more previous years, you may be eligible to take a special minimum tax credit against your regular tax this year. If eligible, you should complete and attach Form 8801, Credit for Prior Year Minimum Tax - Individuals, Estates, and Trusts to claim the minimum tax credit.
taxCredits.p.aotcTT1: Expenses that qualify for the American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC) are qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year. To determine your eligibility use the :claimEducationCredit
taxCredits.p.businessCreditTT1: If you own or operate a your own business you may be eligible for business credits.
taxCredits.p.businessCreditTT2: In order to determine your eligibility and amounts visit :irsTopicBusiness
taxCredits.p.childDependentCareAmountTT1: The total expenses that you may use to calculate the credit may not be more than $3,000 (for one qualifying individual) or $6,000 (for two or more qualifying individuals). Expenses paid for the care of a qualifying individual are eligible expenses if the primary reason for paying the expense is to assure the individual's well-being and protection. If you received dependent care benefits that you exclude or deduct from your income, you must subtract the amount of those benefits from the dollar limit that applies to you.
taxCredits.p.childrenAgesTT1: This credit is for individuals who claim a child as a dependent if the child meets additional conditions.
taxCredits.p.educationCreditWarning: Since you have also entered an input for the American Opportunity Tax Credit, you cannot take both education credits for the same person.
taxCredits.p.elderlyTaxCreditTT1: A credit for taxpayers who are aged 65 or older or retired on permanent and total disability and received taxable disability income for the tax year; AND with an adjusted gross income OR the total of nontaxable Social Security, pensions annuities or disability income under specific limits.
taxCredits.p.energyMotorVehicleTaxCredit: You may be able to take a credit if you place a qualified fuel cell vehicle in service during the tax year. Generally, you can rely on the manufacturer's certification to the IRS that a specific make, model and model year vehicle qualifies for the credit and the amount of the credit for which it qualifies.
taxCredits.p.energyPlugInTaxCreditTT1: You may be able to claim a credit for a qualified vehicle. These credits do phase out.
taxCredits.p.energyRefuelingTaxCreditTT1: You may be entitled to a credit for alternative fuel vehicle refueling property you placed in service during your tax year.
taxCredits.p.foreignTaxCreditTT1: If you paid or accrued foreign taxes to a foreign country or U.S. possession and are subject to U.S. tax on the same income, you may be able to take either a credit or an itemized deduction for those taxes.
taxCredits.p.hasDependentsAccordionInto: You indicated you have a dependent(s). Enter age for each dependent you wish to claim
taxCredits.p.hasDependentsInto: You previously stated you planned to claim dependents. Use the open Child and Dependent Credits section to provide details for any dependent-related tax credits.
taxCredits.p.homeOwnerMortgageTaxCreditT: You may be able to claim this credit if you were issued a qualified Mortgage Credit Certificate (MCC) by a state or local governmental unit or agency under a qualified mortgage credit certificate program.
taxCredits.p.homeOwnerTaxCreditTT1: You may be able to take these credits if you made energy saving improvements to your principal residence during the taxable year.
taxCredits.p.llcTT1: Expenses that qualify for the Lifetime Learning Credit (LLC) are qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year. To determine your eligibility use the :claimEducationCredit
taxCredits.p.numOfChildDependentCareQCTT: You may be able to claim the child and dependent care credit if you paid expenses for the care of a qualifying individual to enable you (and your spouse, if filing a joint return) to work or actively look for work.
taxCredits.p.numOfEitcQCTT1: The EITC or EIC, is a benefit for working people with low to moderate income. To qualify, you must meet certain requirements and file a tax return, even if you do not owe any tax or are not required to file. EITC reduces the amount of tax you owe and may give you a refund.
taxCredits.p.numOfEitcQCTT2: We recommend you use :irsTopicEITC to determine your eligibility for Earned Income Tax Credit.
taxCredits.p.retirementSavingsCreditTT1: If you make eligible contributions to certain eligible retirement plans or to an individual retirement arrangement (IRA), you may be able to take a tax credit. The amount of the saver's credit you can get is generally based on the contributions you make and your credit rate.
taxCredits.p.skipAhead: You may be eligible for some types of tax credits based on the information you entered in previous steps. Complete the previous steps before advancing to this page.
taxCredits.p.subtitle: Tax credits are amounts you subtract directly from your tax obligation.
results.p.nonRefundCreditCTC: Child Tax Credit and Credit for other dependents
aboutYou.p.blindTT1: If you are blind on the last day of the year and you don't itemize deductions, you are entitled to a higher standard deduction.
aboutYou.p.blindTT3: If you aren't totally blind, you must get a certified statement from an eye doctor (ophthalmologist or optometrist) that:
results.h2.box1Header2Future: If you do not submit a Form W-4 to your employer, :yourResults
results.h2.box1Header2DecMsg: It's likely too late in the year to change your withholding, and :yourResults
results.p.salaryIntroParagraph1Future: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck.
results.p.pensionIntroParagraphFuture: To get your desired refund amount, you will need :amount1 withheld from each paycheck.
results.h2.box1Header2: If you do not change your withholding, :yourResults
adjustments.p.seHealthInsuranceTT1: If you're self-employed and have a net profit for the year, you may be eligible for the self-employed health insurance deduction. This is an adjustment to income, rather than an itemized deduction, for premiums you paid on a health insurance policy covering medical care, including a qualified long-term care insurance policy for yourself, your spouse, and dependents. The policy can also cover your child who is under the age of 27 at the end of :pastYear even if the child wasn't your dependent.
adjustments.a.seHealthInsuranceTT1: Chapter 6 of Publication 535, Business Expenses for eligibility information.
adjustments.p.seHealthInsuranceSpouseTT1: If your spouse is self-employed and he/she has a net profit for the year, you may be eligible for the self-employed health insurance deduction. This is an adjustment to income, rather than an itemized deduction, for premiums you paid on a health insurance policy covering medical care, including a qualified long-term care insurance policy for yourself, your spouse, and dependents. The policy can also cover your child who is under the age of 27 at the end of :pastYear even if the child wasn't your dependent.
adjustments.a.seHealthInsuranceSpouseTT1: Chapter 6 of Publication 535, Business Expenses for eligibility information.
adjustments.h2.sepSimpleTT1: SEP, SIMPLE, and other qualified plans
adjustments.p.sepSimpleTT1: If you are self-employed (a sole proprietor or a working partner in a partnership or limited liability company), you must use a special rule to calculate retirement plan contributions for yourself.
adjustments.a.sepSimpleTT1: Self-Employed Individuals – Calculating Your Own Retirement-Plan Contribution and Deduction
adjustments.h2.sepSimpleSpouseTT1: SEP, SIMPLE, and other qualified plans
adjustments.p.sepSimpleSpouseTT1: If your spouse is self-employed (a sole proprietor or a working partner in a partnership or limited liability company), your spouse must use a special rule to calculate retirement plan contributions for themselves.
adjustments.a.sepSimpleSpouseTT1: Self-Employed Individuals – Calculating Your Own Retirement-Plan Contribution and Deduction
taxCredits.label.childDependentCareAmoun: Enter the amount of qualifying work-related childcare expenses
taxCredits.label.numOfChildDependentCare: Enter the number of qualifying children for the Child and Dependent Care Credit
incomeWithholding.label.plannedEstimated: Planning to make estimated tax payments for income such as dividends, interest, distributions from an IRA (not Roth IRAs), 401(k) plan, or a trust.
otherIncome.a.plannedEstimatedTaxPayment: Error: An amount is required to continue.
results.heading.decemberMsgAlert: There is likely not enough time left this year to change your tax withholding
results.p.decemberMesgRefundWarning1: Make sure you're having the right amount withheld to meet your tax obligation next year by using the Tax Withholding Estimator in January.
results.p.decemberMesgOweWarning1: To minimize your potential penalty and the amount you may owe when you file your return, consider making an estimated tax payment by January 15 to cover the shortfall. For more information about making estimated payments, visit :estimatedTaxes.
results.p.decemberMesgOweWarning2: Make sure you're having the right amount withheld to meet your tax obligation next year by using next year's Tax Withholding Estimator early in the year.
results.p.decemberMesgOweWarning3: For questions on the results or recommendations, see our :faq.
results.h2.onlyPastIncomes: You cannot change your withholding, and :yourResults
